description.p: The haywire spell causes a single device of up to 100 lb. to behave randomly and erratically, defying any attempts to bring it under control. Cash registers display random prices and open their money drawers repeatedly. Escalators surge forward, then reverse themselves. Automatic teller machines flash random patrons' account balances on the screen as they spew forth receipts (not money, though).

It's impossible to describe the exact effects of haywire on every modern device. In general, a machine subject to haywire functions as if someone were pressing random buttons or otherwise manipulating it randomly.

Turning off a device subject to a haywire spell doesn't work, because the spell disables the "off" switch. Cutting off the power supply (by unplugging it, for example) disables the device 1d4 rounds later, ending the spell.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the duration is increased by 1 minute per slot, the target weight is increased by 100 lb. per slot and the range is increased by 2.5 ft. per slot.

With this illusion cantrip, you make a small card of slip of paper appear to be a valid identification card of your choosing. For example, you might make a business card look like a driver's license, or a video club card look like an FBI identification card. The card looks visually accurate and contains enough machine readable data to pass cursory inspection; however, not enough to fool sophisticated systems. Thus an illusory drivers license might be enough to convince a traffic official at a roadblock, but an illusory FBI identification card will not grant access to secure premises.

setters.set: a small card or slip of paper

description.p: By touching a single device that contains electronic files, such as a computer, tablet, smart phone, external hard drive or a CD/DVD/Blu-Ray with a magnet, you erase all files on that device. The device is rendered empty of data.

This spell plays havoc with electronic devices, making the use of such devices impossible. Each electronic device in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range is subject to random behavior while it remains within the area. A device not held by a creature automatically affected. If an electronic device is held by a creature, that creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have the device affected by the spell.

At the start of each of your turns, roll a d6 for each affected device to determine its behavior. Except where otherwise indicated, that behavior lasts until the start of your next turn while this spell is in effect.

ul.li: 1: The device behaves randomly and erratically, defying any attempts to bring it under control and functioning as if someone were pressing random buttons or otherwise manipulating it randomly.
2-4: The device freezes and does not function

5: The device experiences a power surge, causing an electric shock to the wielder (if any) and one random creature within 5 feet of the device. Each affected creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking 6d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
6: The device is usable as normal.

description.p: At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the radius of the sphere affected by the spell increases by 5 feet for each slot level above 3rd.
